title.a: Workshop on Web APIs and RESTful Design (WS-REST 2015)

slide.title: Abstract
slide.p: REST's popularity as a design pattern for providing services has steadily gained traction over the last decade. While this is great news because more decentralized and browsable services become available, it also creates the risk of attempting to create REST standards. After looking back on REST's success (and WS-REST's 6-year history), this talk is an attempt to present REST as a pattern and a practice, and not as a technology that needs standardized technologies and tools. As REST practitioners our goal should be to create solutions that are a good fit for their problem space, instead of attempting to create the single one solution that we can simply use everywhere.

slide.title: Using Style Elements to Solve Problems

ul.li: REST is not intended as the answer to all problems in IT
Trading optimization of tight coupling for evolvability of loose coupling
REST works best for large-scale scenarios with decentralized evolution

Open media types allow for extensions and non-breaking versioning
Link types allow to establish new relationships between resources
New media types can be introduced and deployed incrementally
IoT's next step is the Web of Things (WoT)
WoT is nothing more than applying REST to IoT resources
How likely is it that all IoT resources use one media type?
Probably similar to the likelihood that all APIs use the same media type
Why not share patterns instead of trying to share technologies?

Without resource IDs, there can be no REST
There is no specific discovery protocol in the REST style
Without discovery, living in an open and decentralized world is impossible
Discovery is just another service! Here's a rather popular one!
Discovery is covered by REST and does not need special treatment
Formats such as Atom or Activity Streams essentially are discovery protocols
